prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Sensitivity needed: We expect that the typical intensity of the 12CO(2-1) line is 10K or stronger with a velocity line width of a few km/s inferred from the Galactic GMC observations and Cycle 1 observations. In this study, both the spatial and velocity information is important to investigate the dynamics, and then we adopt the desired sensitivity as 0.5 K (rms) with a velocity resolution of 0.3 km/s. From previous ALMA observations of N159W (see Scientific Justification), we expect to detect molecular lines of 13CO (2-1), C18O(2-1) toward the dense clumps with this sensitivity.

Because we observe 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) simultaneously, the tolerance of the setting is very limited as shown in the knowledgebase on Science portal. We set the parameters so that the OT does not issue any errors or warnings. The velocity bandwidth of 153km/s is wide enough to cover the spectra. H30alpha and SiO(5-4) line are expected to have much wider band-width than CO lines, and we set the band width of 1875MHz with a velocity resolution of 2.5km/s for H30alpha and 1.56km/s for SiO(5-4). The choice of the band-width, 1875MHz is to increase the continuum sensitivity.

We would like to resolve high-density cores spatially because the size and the mass distributions are the key for this study. We then choose an angular resolution of 1 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.36pc. The molecular gas is expected to be spatially extended in the primary beam, and then the ACA (7m+TP) will be definitely needed.

Sensitivity needed: We expect that the typical intensity of the 12CO(2-1) line is 10K or stronger with a velocity line width of a few km/s inferred from the Galactic GMC observations and Cycle 1 observations. In this study, both the spatial and velocity information is important to investigate the dynamics, and then we adopt the desired sensitivity as 0.5 K (rms) with a velocity resolution of 0.3 km/s. From previous ALMA observations of N159W (see Scientific Justification), we expect to detect molecular lines of 13CO (2-1), C18O(2-1) toward the dense clumps with this sensitivity.

We set the parameters so that the OT doesn' t issue any errors or warnings. The velocity bandwidth of 153km/s is wide enough to cover the spectra. We then choose an angular resolution of 1 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.36pc. The molecular gas is expected to be spatially extended in the primary beam, and then the ACA (7m+TP) will be definitely needed.

Because we observe 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) simultaneously, the tolerance of the setting is very limited as shown in the knowledgebase on Science portal. We set the parameters so that the OT doesn' t issue any errors or warnings. The velocity bandwidth of 153km/s is wide enough to cover the spectra. H30alpha and SiO(5-4) line are expected to have much wider band-width than CO lines, and we set the band width of 1875MHz with a velocity resolution of 2.5km/s for H30alpha and 1.56km/s for SiO(5-4). The choice of the band-width, 1875MHz is to increase the continuum sensitivity.

We then choose an angular resolution of 1 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.36pc. The molecular gas is expected to be spatially extended in the primary beam, and then the ACA (7m+TP) will be definitely needed.

Sensitivity needed: We expect that the typical intensity of the 12CO(2-1) line is 10K or stronger with a velocity line width of a few km/s inferred from the Galactic GMC observations and Cycle 1 observations. In this study, both the spatial and velocity information is important to investigate the dynamics, and then we adopt the desired sensitivity as 0.5 K (rms) with a velocity resolution of 0.3 km/s. From previous ALMA observations of N159W (see Scientific Justification), we expect to detect molecular lines of 13CO (2-1), C18O(2-1) toward the dense clumps with this sensitivity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Large Magellanic Cloud is the nearest neighbor to the Milky Way, and its nearly face-on view allows us to unambiguously identify young objects associated with GMCs over a galaxy. We classified the GMCs into three types according to the activities of massive star formation, corresponding to the evolutional sequence of the GMCs. One of the features of the GMCs in the LMC is that there are many starless GMCs, suggesting that the timescale in star formation is significantly longer than in the Galaxy. This may be due to the higher ionization degree and smaller cooling rate as a consequence of lower metallicity in the LMC, and it is tempting to speculate that there is a link between populous clusters and the starless GMCs. Our Cycle 1 approved program map 5 GMCs of different GMC types to resolve molecular cloud cores at sub-parsec scales in CO and showed that the molecular clouds consist of many filamentary/clumpy structures with large velocity differences. Here we propose to follow-up on the youngest three of the GMCs, G225, N166 and N171, to probe the molecular cloud structure, which leads to the understanding of the possible origin of high star formation activities in the LMC.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00753.S, "The O stars in the making and their surrounding filamentary clouds in N159: A pursuit of triggered formation in a filamentary collision", Y. Fukui 2015.1.00402.S, "Investigating the formation of high-mass stars in giant molecular clouds in the LMC", T. Onishi
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00554.S, "Most active on-going star formation in the Local Group: Resolving filaments and cloud cores in the LMC", Y. Fukui 2012.1.00603.S, "Tracing evolution of giant molecular clouds in the Large Magellanic Cloud", A. Kawamura 2013.1.01091.S, "Sub-parsec scale structure of quiescent molecular clouds possibly pre-forming clusters", A. Kawamura
